item.title: Human vs JSON output formatting: avoid mixing concerns
item.description: Two of the original ideas about Unix is that each program should do one thing and that programs should be able to be combine so they consume each others' output. This led to the convention and tradition that Unix command line programs produce output that's relatively easy for other programs to parse.

item.title: Thoughts on the ‚ÄúWiner WordPress Tease‚Äù ‚Äì Andy Sylvester's Web
item.description: Dave Winer has been promoting his editor for WordPress sites, called WordLand, leading up to his keynote speech at WordCamp Canada in October 2025, as well as hinting about other WordPress-related projects. Recently, he asked readers to ‚ÄúThink Different About WordPress‚Äú, where he talks about how WordPress supports editing features that Mastodon and Bluesky do not support (linking, no character limits, and other features). WordPress also has ‚Äúexcellent support‚Äù for RSS and rssCloud, and has a ‚Äúdeep and powerful API‚Äú.

item.title: Chess Variant
A look at a P2P camera (LookCam app)
item.description: I‚Äôve got my hands on an internet-connected camera and decided to take a closer look, having already read about security issues with similar cameras. What I found far exceeded my expectations: fake access controls, bogus protocol encryption, completely unprotected cloud uploads and firmware riddled with security flaws. One could even say that these cameras are Murphy‚Äôs Law turned solid: everything that could be done wrong has been done wrong here.

item.title: Using Claude Code to modernize a 25-year-old kernel driver ‚Äì Dmitry Brant
item.description: As a bit of background, one of my hobbies is helping people recover data from old tape cartridges, such as QIC-80 tapes, which were a rather popular backup medium in the 1990s among individuals, small businesses, BBS operators, and the like. I have a soft spot for tape media; there‚Äôs something about the tactile sensation of holding these tapes in my hands that makes the whole process very joyful, even though QIC tapes are notorious for their many design flaws. With some careful inspection and reconditioning, the data on these tapes is still totally recoverable, even after all these years.

item.title: Ten Years of D3D12
item.description: For those of us that have been using it from the start, it can be hard to believe that Direct3D 12 has been around for ten years now. Windows 10 was released on July 29th 2015, and D3D12 has been with us ever since. While it‚Äôs true that this is the longest we‚Äôve gone between major D3D version updates, it‚Äôs also not fair to say that the API has remained static.

item.title: My Video Production Stack (for YouTube)
item.description: There are two barriers to publishing videos on YouTube. The first one is getting over thinking you are cringe and the second one is video editing. You have to battle the first one on your own, but I‚Äôm hoping that with what I share below, you can ease the burden of the latter. No-hands editing, processing and publishing The goal of this video production stack is to take a raw video, then automatically edit it, transcribe it, come up with timestamped chapter markers for the YouTube description, and upload it to my YouTube channel. Basically this is a fully automatic publishing workflow after the point I hit stop on the record button.

item.title: Juggling multiple SSH_AUTH_SOCKs in¬†tmux ‚Äì mark shroyer, dot com
item.description: This post is about a portable Unix shell script, socklink.sh, written to keep SSH_AUTH_SOCK working within a long-running tmux session‚Äîeven when switching between multiple clients that have different SSH agents, whether those clients are simultaneously connected or attaching and detaching over time. I also digresses into what I‚Äôve learned from writing and testing a cross-platform shell script in¬†2025.
